item.title: Reasons I'm Leaving (traditional) Social Media
item.description: Polarization: division into two sharply distinct opposites. Privacy: the state of being free from public attention or unsanctioned intrusion. Attention: the ability or power to keep the mind on something. These are the primary reasons I’m leaving the more traditional social media sites. In this article, I’ll be making the case for why these traditional sites move us in a direction away from the optimal positions in these three important areas of modern living, and I’ll be linking alternative tools below that supplement or replace these original websites more effectively.

item.title: The JuliaLang Paradox
item.description: The beginning of this post is going to sound ridiculous, but I promise it is 100% true. One night went to bed trying to remember the name of an interesting programming language that I heard about a while back. It supposedly had a lot of super nifty features, and was some strange hybrid of multiple languages that still somehow worked. I was intrigued, but couldn’t remember, so I decided to just go to sleep and figure it out in the morning.

item.title: Maximizing Productivity Via The Command Line
item.description: Those who know me know I am a huge fan of GNU/Linux (for you Stallman), and I originally got into it to help me with a few chemistry simulations in my quantum mechanics and statistical dynamics course in undergrad. Specifically, my professor made a huge deal about turning in lab reports that were formatted ever-so precisely, and to kill two birds with one stone, I installed Linux on my computer to help me learn and interface with the supercomputer, and installed LaTeX to help with the lab report issue.
